title: indentify my sans-serif lead type
content:
About a year ago I purchased some 14-pt. sans-serif lead type labeled “metroline.” Its great stuff— and I use it constantly. However, I’m thinking that its mislabeled. I can’t find any listing anywhere for a font called “metroline”— and the ones with similar names look NOTHING like my type. Perhaps the experts here might recognize it. A printed sample is at:

[http://www.magicfishpress.com/eric/metroline.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20050528001232/http:/www.magicfishpress.com/eric/metroline.jpg)

I don’t know who the type founders might have been, either. No markings and no original packaging.

Good luck! Thanks for having a look!

eric wilcox  
magic fish press
author: SetsofWaves

comments.content: Looks like Lightline Gothic, an ATF face.

Mark, looks like Lightline Gothic to me as well, though there was a Monotype version of this. This difference could be determined by the body; nick and feet.

Eric, looks like you nut quadded the interword spacing here. (?)

Gerald

Is there a reference guide for identifying lead type by foundry?  
Something that shows foundry marks or as Gerald mentioned how _This difference could be determined by the body; nick and feet_ ?

Richard

There are a number of reference sources for pinmarks but the only one that I know of online is at Briar Press

[http://www.oneart.com/cgi-bin/briarpress/show.cgi?db=pin&uid=default&display=1&file=pin\_marks-introduction&layout=default](http://web.archive.org/web/20050528001232/http:/www.oneart.com/cgi-bin/briarpress/show.cgi?db=pin&uid=default&display=1&file=pin_marks-introduction&layout=default)

In most cases, Monotype will not have a pinmark. Off hand I can only think of two Monotype operations that pinmarked their type, Baltimore Type Foundry and Phoenix Type Foundry.

And, to make it more confusing, not all firms casting foundry type (as opposed to Monotype) had pinmarks.

Gerald

Richard

The second part of this has to do with nicks and feet. While there are certain general casting practices, there are far too many variables involved to use either of these as positive identification. Examples:

In many cases Monotype might have no feet, in others it may have, depending upon the type of Monotype caster. On the other hand, foundry, which often has distinct feet, as this is actually how the jet is removed, doesn’t always have them either. European metal foundry that has been ground to Anglo-American type height is easily identifiable as the feet have been ground off and the grinding pattern is usually discernible. But even here, several American firms that licensed European fonts often cast them at type high with feet or made special arrangements to have them cast that way at the foreign foundry.

Metal type technology is as much of a mess in its variations as the continual evolution of digital type formats.

Gerald

Just wanted to thank everyone for the help!

I appreciate it!

And Gerald— you’ll have to bear with me… I’m a (very) beginning printer. What do you mean when you say “nut quadded”?

eric wilcox

A nut quad is the space between words.  
Nut is a compositor’s way of saying en to differentiate it from em (Mutton)  
Tim

But an en-space is much too much between words.

hhp
